notesStmt.note: This edition compares the first 1826 published edition of Mitford's play Foscari against the manuscript version of the play held in the British Library, and against the final published text of 1854.

The hand-writing in the manuscript verion of the play appears to be that of a copyist rather than Mary Russell Mitford. The manuscript, which was submitted to the Lord Chamberlain's Office for review, is dated 30 October 1826 and is titled Foscari, a Tragedy in Five Acts.

handNotes.handNote: The manuscript of 1826 does not appear to be written in Mitford's hand, but rather in the hand of a copyist. A second hand in pencil has renumbered the pages for inclusion in this volume of Plays from the Lord Chamberlain's Office, folio pages 341-450.

editorialDecl.p: Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next in the manuscript. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice," “sic," and “reg" to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

Foscari: A Tragedy, London, G. B. Whittaker, 1826

app.rdg: The subject of the following Play is taken from a domestic tragedy in the history of Venice, and was suggested to the Authoress by an interesting narrative of that event in Dr. Moore's Travels. It is scarcely, perhaps, necessary to say here in prose, what the Prologue repeats in verse, that her piece was not only completed, but actually presented to Covent Garden Theatre before the publication of Lord Byron'swell-known drama: a fact which happily exculpates her from any charge of a vain imitation of the great Poet, or of a still vainer rivalry.

She has now only the pleasant task of acknowledging her obligations to those whose eminent and united talents ensured the success of her Tragedy. To Mr. Young, for his masterly and pathetic delineation of the heart-broken father; to Mr. Kemble, (that embodied spirit of
chivalry to whom all that is gallant and knightly seems to belong as of right) for the brilliant exertion of his powers in Francesco; to Mr. Warde, for the consummate subtlety and the commanding intellect which he threw into Erizzo; to Mr. Serle, for the pure and gentle pathos of his Cosmo; and, though last, far from least, to Mrs. Sloman, for her chaste an affecting Camilla, she is most deeply indebted. Nor ought she to omit the sincere tribute of her gratitude to Mr. Fawcett, for the zealous kindness with which he superintended the production of her Play; and to the performers in general for the interest they took in its success. She begs them all to accept her heartfelt thanks.

The subject of the following Play is taken from a domestic tragedy in the history of Venice, and was suggested to the Authoress by an interesting narrative of that event in Dr. Moore's Travels. It is scarcely, perhaps, necessary to say here in prose, what the Prologue repeats in verse, that her piece was not only completed, but actually accepted at Covent Garden Theatre, before the publication of Lord Byron'swell-known drama.

div.head: Epilogue to "Foscari"
div.l: Just now I thought I knew it every word--
The prettiest Epilogue you ever heard;
But in the crisis of the Prompter's call,
A true "good natured friend" has marred it all--
He said "The play was fair"--"you might forgive--
"But in this age no tragedy could live;
"An age which no high thought or passion knows--
"An age of Paper, Levity, and Prose:"
I stormed; and having lost my proper cue,
Beg to refer the argument to you,
Assur'd you'll find, in spite of canting sages,
Our own the most poetical of ages!--
What though our sadden'd walls no more unfolds
The Lottery's rich promises of gold,
Though Fortune's darling wheels for ever still
And patriot hands have torn her final bill,
She yet averts, by many a kindly quirk
The sad alternative to starve or work;
While commerce holds alliance with Romance
And Fancy lends her brightest hues to chance;
Bids airy visions hover o'er the Strand
And makes the Stock Exchange enchanted land--
There, the rapt merchant dreams of Sinbad's vale
And catalogues in thought, its genii for sale--
There, dives to Vigo's time-unaltered caves
And borrows millions from the courteous waves--
There, nobly scorning England's prose per cents,
Takes, at his whim, a share in governments
Now makes some new republic's cause his own,
Now bleeds in pocket for an ancient throne,
Feels his purse lighten as Poyais desponds,
And cheapens Freedom in Columbian Bonds--
Delighted sees, released from despot sway
A mighty people rise--in act to pray.
Nay, touch'd by human nature's holiest plea,
Finds in Change Alley true Thermopolie,
And by deep interest urged and classic pity,
Gives to poor Greece a loan and--a committee--
But let that pass--one thing at least is clear
Old English kindness still has refuge here;
Here where its influence blest from times of yore,
May it to-night relieve one trembler more,
Bid generous critics mildly judge her flaws,
And move the Fair to own a sister's cause!
For riches famed of yore, and once as free,free
As her own element, the bounding sea,
Fair Venice now, fallenfall'n from her "palmy state,"palmy state,
Broods o'er herher palace-city desolate;
Each mart deserted, each Palladian Hallhall
Vacant and ruinous,ruinous proclaims her fall.
Yet still one triumph of her ancient fame
Gilds her decay, and lingers round her name:;
Tis'Tis that beneath the proud Venetian dome
The Tragic Muse hath fixedfix'd her favourite home;
'Tis that her very name bidsmakes young hearts glow
With deep remembrance of some glorious woe.
There Shylock whetted his relentless knife;
There poor Othello won his murdered wife;
There Pierre, stout traitor, the awed State defied;
There Jaffier lovedlov'd, and Belvidera died,died.
And there the immortal Bard, who all too soon
Fell in the blaze of Fame's effulgent noon,
Lamented Byron!In the Foscari manuscript, Byron is underlined in a different color (possibly with a pencil and thus was not likely underlined by the scribe. twice a tale hath told
Of princely anguish in the days of old:
div.note: The prologue as it appears in the scan of the 1826 published edition of Foscari available on NCCO breaks off after this line. The rest of the prologue as produced here notes differences between the manuscript version and the 1854 edition of the play only.
div.l: How 'gainst the Senate Falieri fired,Faliero fired
With vengeful hate by their stern doom expired;
And hishis severer fate, condemned to try
His guiltless son, the good Doge Foscari.
That tale of woe, but with a loweran humbler flight.
And weaker wing, our Authoress of to-night
Hath brought before ye. Deem not of it worse
That 'tis a theme made famoussacred by his verse.
Ere his bold Tragedy burst into day,
Her trembling hand had closed this woman's play.
A different track she followedfollows---Oh! forgive
Her errors, ye, who bid the Drama live!
To your indulgence she commends her cause,
And hopes, yet dares not askclaim, your kind applause.

div.stage: Count Erizzo & and Celso meeting Donato.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Good morrowGood-morrow, Count Erizzo, you are early.
Are you bound to the Palace?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: AyeAy, Donato,
The common destination; but I go
With an old friend.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What Celso!What, Celso, thou turned Courtiercourtier!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: I am a suitor to his Highness, Sir,
With Count Erizzo's aid.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What is your suit?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: One of the ProcuratorsprocuratorsThe Procurator of St. Mark's was the second-most prestigious lifetime office in the Republic of Venice (the most prestigious was that of the Doge). died last night;
And honest Celsohere would fain succeed
To that good office.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: None more capable.!
You will not fail.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: ScarcelyScarcely, I think;---and yet
I hardly know. The old Doge likes me not:
There have been murmersmurmursmurmurs in the Senate, CousinSenate, cousin,senate, cousin,
At these long wasting wars; & he I hearand he, I hear,
Suspects me. I have doubts. From you indeedyou, indeed,thee, indeed,
One word--

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: It shall be said. Give me the paper.
YesYes, at one word from me---Thethe Doge and I
Are friends, old friends, the friends of forty yearsyears;
Besides we have a pair of hopeful Sonssons,
Friends from the cradle upwardsupwards.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: And those friends
May soon be brothers. Will not thy Camilla
Be Foscari's bridebride, when his rough Mistressmistress War
Shall loose him from her arms?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: AyeAy; he'll return
Too soon;,, whene'er he comes, to steal away
My age's darling. Yet is he a boyboyyouth
Full of high thoughts, a noble,noble princely boy;youthboy,
Kindly &and generous; one that may deserve
Even her.---Well, give me this petitionpetition, Count.
Look on the post as certain.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: How can II repay
Repay---He's gone. Think'st thou he will succeedsucceed?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: I know not. Either way looksworks well for us.
If he succeed, then will our party gain
firmer foot in Venice; if he failfail,
We gain Donato.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Say'st thou so?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: I know him.
He's of a temper kind & quick & warm,kind, and quick, and warm;
A powerful partizan, but easily swayedsway'd
By flattery or anger. Of such tools
Are Faction's ranks composed, not officeredofficered.
Celso, we'll have this Doge unbonnettedunbonneted,
This Doge,Doge who wears his load of fourscorefour-score years
Easier than I my forty. He contemns
Me and my brother nobles;: he may learn
To know and fear our power. I tell youthee, Sir,
These brows of mine do ache for that same bonnettbonnet,
And e'erere this day be ended---

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: 'Tis'Tis, my lordLord,
A golden moment. The young Foscari
Is safe with Sforza in the Milan wars.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Would I were sure of that! This is indeed
The only moment. CelsoCelso, I have here,
How intercepted boots not, letters from
Both generals to the Senate. They have gained
A Signal Victorysignal victory; Brescia is freed;
And Sforza gives the unshared, unmingledunshared unmingled praise
To Foscari. We must dethroneunthrone the Doge
Er'eEre this news reach the Citycitycity; for the people
Adore the Foscari. Faugh! I am weary
ofOf this good Doge, this venerable Doge,
This popular Doge, this Doge who courts &and wooeswooswoos
The noisy rabble, whilst the Senators
He elbows from their seats. And for the Sonson,
With his hot valourvalor &and proud lack of pride---
I hate them both. We must not lose an hour---;
The people must not hear---

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: The Senate hates them.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: AyeAy, but the Senate---

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Well, my Lord, the Senate--

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Fy! I am one of them; I must not tell
The secrets of the Council. We are not
So stubborn as we seem; the popular voice
Finds there an echo; & besidesand besidesand besides, the Doge
Hath friends. Here comes one.
A fair morning to you.youyou,
Count Zeno. I have scarcely seen you since
Your lingering Sickness;sickness. youYou look cheerily.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: The air of this new day is sweet and cheeringfreshening,
And breathes a health into the veins. I trust
You need no renovating; yet to step
From a sick bed and &a dark silent room
Into the fresh &pure and balmy air of June,
With the bright Sunsun walkinglighting so blue a skysky,
And sparkling on the waters,waterswaters;waters all aroundaround,
Full of the living noise of trade or mirth,
Air, earthearth, and seasea, all motion,motion---it is like
Returning from the tomb,tomb to this fair world
Of life and sunshine! Such delight is well
Worth a sharp fever.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Nevertheless am I
Content with your report. A homelier joy
Suffices me.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: You are the happier man.
Are you for the Palacepalace?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: No. weWe wait a friend.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Then I must say good morrowgood-morrow. I am somewhat
In haste to dayto-day.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Good morrowmorrow, Count.
That man
Wears in his courtly smile the consciousness
Of his high influence---the prime favoritefavouritefavorite he!
Did you not see how graciously he stooped
To me,me his equal, even as he had been
Himself a Princeprince---proud Minion?minion!---Doge bewareDoge, beware!
Beware!!--- Look, look, Donato too hath found
A check!? SeeSee, how he chafes! seeSee!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Take thy paper!
I am refused. Good MorrowGood morrowGood-morrow!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: NayNay, come back.
Can this be possible? Refused! Donato
Refused by FoscariFoscari!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: I was a fool
To ask;;---a double fool to pin my faith
Upon this Doge's ermine.

sp.speaker: Celso.
sp.l: I regret
More than my failure the indignity---

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Forget itit, Sir..---How go these MilanWarswars??---
I say, Erizzo, would'stcould'st thou have believed
The proudest Hehe in Venice would have dared
To treat me with such scorn?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: What! Diddid he scorn thee?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: He chid me, schooled me, blamed my easy tempertemper,
That lent an ear to every cunning taletale,
A voice to every false designing Knaveknave.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Dared he!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: And this to me! Why art thou not
AmazedAmazed, Erizzo?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: No. It but confirms
What I have heard &and scarce believed. The Doge
Is grown so old that he forgets his friends.
Men say---it can't be true---&and yet men say---

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: That the Doge repents his son's betrothment
To thy Camilla.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: He shall never wed her.
Sir, if this Doge were Kingking of all the earth
He might have found a higherhigher, prouder title
In father to Camilla! They are free.
Camilla's claims shall never interrupt---
What is his project?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Our great enemyenemy,
The Duke of MilanDuke of Milan, hath a youngyoung, fair daughterdaughter,
And sheshe, they say---

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Tush! I have seen herher, man!
A dark-broweddark browed wench, a beetle browedbeetle-browed,beetle-browed---no more
To match with my Camilla,Camilla than that Gondola

With the Bucentaur!Bucentaur?The Bucentaur was a large, stately barge used by the Doge of Venice when performing the annual Marriage of the Sea ceremony. A gondola, by contrast, is a small flat-bottomed Venetian boat.---I will backback, &and tell him
That Foscari is free. Mine own Camilla!
My prattlingprattling, pretty one! I'll back and tell him.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: No; rather come with me. What I have said
Is hearsay or conjecture; what is suretruecertain
Is the misgovernment, the public wrongs
Of this old Foscari, too old to sway
The power of Venice. This is not a place
For such discourse. Come with me to my Palacepalace.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: I thought he loved my daughter!

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Aside. Thou art sure.

div.stage: An Apartment in the Ducal Palace.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Good morrowGood-morrow to your Highness.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Dearest ZenoZeno,
This is no common pleasure. Thou the latest
Of our late revellers, whom the sun scarce sees
'TillTill half his course be run---

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Oh! good my lordLord,
I meet him often er'eere I go to bedbed,
The bright reproachful tell-tale!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: To see theethee,
But lately risen from a sharp sickness too,too,
Afoot so early! There must be some causecause,
Some kind or pleasant cause---What brings theethee, CountCount?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: This letterletter!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: No petition for the post
Vacant by poor Venoni's death?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I should have grieved within one little hour
To say twice No to two dear friends--Youfriends. You met
Donato?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Yes;Yes, so chafed he saw me not.
Your Highness knows his tempertemper.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: And I fear
Tried it too much. He asked of me that office
For a known villain, an unusual compound
Of ruffian, &ruffian and of knave, the follower
Of his kinsmankinsman,kinsman Count Erizzo.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Then the Count
Was waiting for Donato. I am grieved
He should be so companioned.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: He flung from me
Er'eEre I could tell him that the post was given
To Signor Loredano, a ripe scholar
Pining in penury, at the pressing instance
Of his own son.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Cosmmo! How like is that
To his unwearied kindnesskindness.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: There is notnot,
Unless I may except my Foscari,
A youth in Venice who can vie in aught
With Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: And they are as different
As the bright Sun &sun and and gentle moon, the Seasea
In sparkling motion &and the quiet landland.
The one a stirringstirring, bravebrave, &and honest soldier,
The other a pale student.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Bless them both,both
My noble boys! They have always loved like brothersbrothers,
And soon I hope my pretty sweet Camilla
Will give them that dear title.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Have you had
Tidings of Foscari lately?

sp.speaker: Dage.
sp.l: Not for long;long,
Longer than common.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Last night at St. Mark's
There was a rumour floating--none could trace
It'sIts source---of a great victory obtained
By Foscari and Sforza.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Heaven grant it!
Sure we shall hear to dayto-day..--NowNow, dearest Count,
What is your will? You led the old man on
To talk of his dear children, 'tilltill in sooth
He had forgotten the whole world. Now say
What is that scroll?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: My lord---I almost fear---
Dost thou believe in soothsayers?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: No!--Yes!Yes!--
Not much.--much. whyWhy dost thou ask?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Wilt thou not answer?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Count ZenoCount Zeno, thou art one to whom, being wise,
A wise man may confess the cherished folly
That lurks within his breast. But tell it not
To foolsfools, good Zeno.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Then thou dost believe?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I have some cause. What! Did'stdidst thou never hear
Of the old prediction that was verified
When I became the Doge?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: An old prediction!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Some seventy years ago--it seems to me
As fresh as yesterday!yesterday--being then a lad
No higher than my hand, idle as an heir,
And all made up of gay &and truant sports,
I flew a kitekite, unmatched in shape or sizesize,
Over the river--we were at our house
Upon the Brenta then; it soared aloft,aloft
Driven by the lightsomelight vigorous breezes from the seasea,
Soared buoyantly, till the diminished specktoy
Grew smaller than the falcon when she stoops
To dart upon her prey. I sent for cordcord,
Servant on Servantservant topplinghurrying, 'tilltill the kite
Shrank to the size of a beetle;: still I called
For cord, &andand sent to summon father, mother,
My little sisters, my old halting nurse--,--
I would have had the whole world to survey
Me &and my wondrous kite. It still soared on,
And I stood,stood bending back in ecstasyextasy,
My eyes on that small point, clapping my handshands,
And shouting, &and half envying it the flight
That made it a companion of the stars,
When close beside me a deep voice exclaimedexclaimed--
AyeAy, Mount! Mount! Mount!mount! mount! mount!--I started back &back, and saw
A tall and aged woman, one of the wild
Peculiar people,people whom wild Hungary sends
Roving thro'through every land. She drew her cloak
About her, turned her black eyes up to HeavenHeaven,
And thus pursued;:--Aye;Aye,Ay, like his fortunesfortunes, mountmount,
The future Doge of Venice! And before
For very wonder any one could speak
She disappeared.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Strange! Hast thou never seen
That woman since?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I never saw her more.
After a slight brief search, the wonder sank
Into a jest;. My mother for awhilea while
Called me her pretty Doge, her madcap DogeDoge,
And rangran a thousand fondling changes through
On that proud title; and my sisters long
Talked of the tall Hungarian. None believed
ButSave my old nurse.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: And thou?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Long time in me
The seeds of faith lay dormant; till at last
As youth's gay wildness sobered, &and ambition
Grew stronger in my soul, the prophecy
Knocked at my thoughts, &and I by fits believed
That which I wished were true. Now for thy scrollscroll;--
Whence comes it?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Even such an aged crone,
So tall, so habited, stayed me last night
At my own door, &and with an earnest voice,
Her shaking hand prest on my arm, implored
ThatThat, as I loved the good Doge Foscari,
I would at his first waking give him this.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: She must be dead! Full seventy years ago--
And then her locks were grizzled!!--She is dead.
And whatwhat, at fourscore yearsyears, have I to do
With fate or fortune! My long race is run:.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Read it at least.

sp.speaker: Doge.

p.quote: "The Ducalducal bonnet trembles on thy brow, Doge of VeniceDoge of Venice, trembles andtrembles--and will fall, though the stars themselves shewshow me not when. Grant the first boon that shall be asked of thee tomorrowto-morrow, or before the next sun rises thy very heart shall be rent in twaintwain."

sp.l: Grant the first boon! WhyWhy, my good Signor Celso,
This is too palpable. Grant the first boon!
Make thee the Procurator! Fy! Fy! Fy!
Erizzo's talent hath forsaken him;
This cheat is shallow. They have heard the tale
I told thee, &and this paltry poor device--
Off to the windswaveswaves and winds!

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Yet hath the Countcount
A party in the state; and for DonatoDonato,
Kind, hasty, generous &and beloved, his power
May vie with thine.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: But never will be used
Against meme, Zeno. I should hate myself
Could I suspect Donato. CountCount,we'll go
Together to the Senate. Thou shalt see
The quick relenting of his sudden wrath,
His graceful self rebukeself-rebuke, his honest love.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: 'IllI'll gladly be converted.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Doubt him not.

div.stage: An Apartment in the Donato PalacePalace.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: LauraLaura, hast thou seen Cosmo?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Not to dayto-day.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: SureSure, he'll not cheat us of his early smiles,
His gay goodmorrowgood-morrow, that best joy of home
When dear friends meet in morning cheerfulness.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: And such a cheerfulness, &! and such a smile!
None are like his.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: None! Hast thou never seen
The heaven of kindness,kindness that in Foscari's eyes
Shines under those dark brows? And I'm the Sistersister
Of that dear Cosmo, the selected bride
Of that still dearer Foscari! Oh cousinOh, cousinOh, cousin,
I am the blessedest creature that e'er trod
This laughing earth! There is but only one
Can hope to be so happy;--Thou perchancethou, perchancethou, perchance,
When Cosmo--
We were speaking of thee.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Well,
I trust fair maids. My gentle lady LauraLaura,
Say yes to that.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Feed not man's vanityvanity;
Let not thy blushes answeranswer.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Sister minemine,
'Tis thou art clothed in blushes. Why the Dawndawn
Opening her ardent eyes, &and shaking wide
Her golden locks on the Adriatic wave,
The bright Aurora, she is sad &and pale
And spiritless compared to thee. Hast thou
Been Psyche's errand?An allusion to the four tasks imposed upon the mythological Psyche by her lover Cupid's mother, Venus, in Lucius Apuleius' Metamorphoses. orOr hath some sweetfair vision
Lapt thee in loveliness?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I think I dreamt
Of Heavenheaven; for I was in a place where Carecare
And Fear & Sorrowfear and sorrow camelive not, self sustainedself-sustained
On wings,wings such as the limnerslimner's cunning lends A limner is a painter of portraits.
To the Seraphim &Seraphim, and singing,singing like a bird
From the deep gladness of a merry heart
The whole night long. And when the morning came
And I was awakenedawakened in this workdaywork-day world,
The spell was on me still, &still; and still is on
The lightsomenessbuoyancy, the joy, the certain hope
Of happiness. BrotherBrother, are there no news
Of Foscari?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: None certain. Yet is there
A balmynessbalminess of hope; & gladsomeand stirring rumours
Come pattering round usus, with a pleasant sound,
Like the large drops before a summer shower.
They talk of Foscari and victory--

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There hath been thenthen been a battle. Is he safe?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: As safe as I myself.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Fy! what a fool
Am I to tremble so! And art thou sure?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: There is no certainty, but such a Hopehope
As is her forerunner. Hath not my father
Heard of this victory?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: He hath been long
Gone to the Palace, &palace, and wished youthee to follow.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Gladly. I have a good man's gratitude
To pay to the good Doge. I must away
Or I shall miss the Senate.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thou wilt send
The tidingstidings, Cosmo?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Surely.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Good tidingstidings, Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Yes. My pretty cousin
Hast thou no charge to give?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Why,Why bring this taletale,
This happy tale thyself.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: AyeAy, come thyself,thyself
Dear Cosmo, & Farewelland farewell.
Let us to the high balcony. I need
Fresh air &and sun &and sparkling sights &and sounds
To help sustain this happiness, this hopehope,
Which weighs almost like fear. My Dearest Comedearest, come.

div.stage: Count Erizzo, Donato &Donato andDonato, and Senators.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: He rules us as a King; king--this Foscari--,
An absolute King!king, Haughty &haughty and imbecile
As any Eastern sovereign! He degrades
The old Nobilitynobility, contemns the Senate;,
And cringes to the people--a mob courtier!
A greedy swallower of popular praise!

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: He hates the noblesNobles.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: But this very day
Did he refuse to my dear Kinsmankinsman here
A postpost, that he requested for a man,man
Who long hath served the Statestate.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Refuse Donato?!!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Even so. He is of the Senate, is the head
Of an old powerful house, is rich, is noblenoble,
Is nobly loved:. Are not these wrongscrimes enough
To stir our Doge's wrath?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: No more of this.!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Then his misgovernment, his tedious wars,
His waste of blood &and treasure, that his sonson,
ThatThe idol of the soldiery, may glut
His lust of glorious battle! Senators,
Why should we thus submit to what we hate?
Why crouchbow to whom we made? The Doge is now
Too old for his high office. Good my lordslords,
Let us resume our power. Is there no brow
In Venice that may bear this Ducalducal crown
ButSave one? Will it not sit as gracefully
On vigorous manhood's clustering curls? On thinethine,
Donato? Or PisaniOr, Pisani,Or Pisani, upon thine?
Or any man of us? LordsLords, have ye changed
Your purpose? That the Doge may be deposed
Is the fixed law of Venice. Are ye firm?
This is the moment.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: He must be unthroned.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Then be it done to dayto-day.

sp.speaker: 2nd Sen.
sp.l: 'IllI'll join thethee, Count.

sp.speaker: 3rd Sen.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: DonatoDonato, thou wilt best propose--

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Oh no! He hath been harsh--but I have loved him.--
We are old friends.

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Do it thyselfthyself, Erizzo.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: But gently, reverently.
sp.stage: Enter Doge, ZenoCount Zeno, &and other Senators.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: My gracious lordslords,
I greet ye well--! weWe are no truants, Sirs!sirs,Sirs,
This full assemblage honours our fair Venice,
Honours her Senators,senators. Signor Donato--
Nay shun me not--Thatthat post was promised to--
Thou wilt not hear--! I have too often borne
With thy infirmity. Forget not, Sirsir,
That thou'stthou'rt my friend, or I must needs remember
That I'm thy Princeprince. Now to our business lords!business, lords.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Are there no letters from the Armyarmy?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: None.
But there is through the Citycity a loud bruit
Of Victoryvictory.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: In a well ordered statewell-ordered state,
There is no pause for rumour; Certaintycertainty
Outspeeds her lying rival.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Think'st thou Countthou, count,thou, Count,
That my old heart is quiet in this pause?
Thou hast no boy in yonder battle fieldbattle-field,
Or thou would'st know how thirstily the Soulsoul
Of a father pants in his suspense for truth,
One single drop of sweet or bitter truth.
Who's that?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Cosmo Donato, please you Siryou, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: OhOh, our young Secretary.Secretary!secretary? Sit by me,
I had just missed theethee, Cosmo. Was thy friend
Content?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: OhOh, never gratitude was clothed
In such pure joy!. I would your Highness saw
The happiness you caused.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Hush! Count ErizzoCount Erizzo,
You were about to speak.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: And yetI was;I was; &and yet
I gladly would delay, gladly resign
A painful dutyduty.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: If it touch me, Sir,
Speak.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Is there notnot, my lord, a law in VeniceVenice,
That if the DogeDoge, by sickness, grief or agegrief, or age,
Become incapable, he be removed?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: There is, say. Say on.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: What need I to say more?!
Know we not all the good Doge Foscari
Is turned of fourscore years? Fitter for him
To lay down the proud bonnet, which doth weigh
So heavily on those white hairs, &and pass
In calmcalm, serene repose the evening hours
Of his unsullied life. So shall his sun,
Setting in tranquil beauty, leave a train
Of pure &and cloudless light; so praised &and loved
Shall he sink down to rest.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: This is not all.
On! On!On, on, my lord!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Fitter for us a man
Who shall remember in this Statestate of Venice
There is another power,power great as himselfhimself,
And greater than the people. Howsoe'erHowsoe'er,
Thou hast the bearing, Doge, of a born Princeprince,--prince,
To usus, thy subjects, thou art but the head
Of the Venetian Noblesnobles. Thy proud rank
Was given by them, thy equals. Each great name
That now surrounds thee hath in turn adorn'dadorned
Thy splendid Office; notoffice. Not a noble house
But is a link in the resplendantresplendent chain
Of old Venetian Storystory. We are born
Lords of the Adriatic--Adriatic; not a name
But hath been vowed her spouse!. Think not such namessuch namessuch names
Are common sounds; they have a music in them,
An odorous recollection;, they are part
Of the old glorious Pastpast. Their country knows
And loves the lofty echo,echo which gives back.back
The memory of the buried Greatgreat; & we,and we
Their son'ssons--OhOh, our own names are watchwords to us
That call to valour &and to victory,
To virtuegoodness &and to freedom. This hast thou
Forgotten. Every creeping artizanartisan,
Every hard-handed,hard-handed smoky slave is nearer
To our great Doge than we.: To to them all smiles
And princely graciousness;--to us all frowns
And kingly pride. Fitter for us a Doge
Of a congenial spiritspirit, to preside
Over our councils, &and to guard &and guide
The Senate&and the State.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Perhaps Erizzo
Would deign to wear this care-encompassed crown?
Fy! Fy!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: My voice is for Donato, Sir!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: My father Doge of Venice? Never! Never!
He will not, must not, shall not. All the world
Would join in one reproach; the very stones
Of Venice would cry out; and we, his children---
Oh we should die of grief and shame! What he
Supplant his friend, his dearest friend? Oh never!
Father, thou wilt not?

sp.speaker: Sen.
sp.l: Silence!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Signor Cosmo
Thou art not yet a Senator.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: My lords,
I pray your pardon; but if I had seen
A venomed serpent coiling round his limbs
And pressing him within its deadly clasp,
Would ye have blamed the cry that Nature sent?---
Thou wilt not be the Doge?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Never!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: My father
Forgive me that I feared. How could I fear!
Forgive me.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Noble boy!---Hast thou said all?
That I am old, and that I love the people?
Are these my crimes? Oh I am doubly guilty!
I love them all, even ye that love me not!
I cannot chuse but love ye, for ye are
Venetians, quick, and proud, and sparkling eyed,
Venetians, brave and free. Ye are the lords
Of the bright sea-built city, beautiful
As storied Athens; or the gorgeous pride
Of Rome, eternal Rome; greater than kings
Are ye Venetian nobles---ye are free;
And that is greatness and nobility,
The source and end of power. That I have made
Liberty common as the common air,
The sun-light, or the rippling waves that wash
Our walls; that every citizen hath been
Free as a Senator; that I have ruled
In our fair Venice, as a father rules
In his dear household, nothing intermitting
Of needful discipline, but quenching fear
In an indulgent kindness; these ye call
My crimes. They are my boasts. Yes, I do love
The honest artizans; there's not a face
That smiles up at me with a kindly eye
But sends a warmth into my heart, a glow
Of buoyant youthfulness. Age doth not freeze
Our human sympathies; the sap fails not
Although the trunk be rugged. Age can feel,
And think, and act. Oh noble Senators,
Ye do mistake my crime. I am too young;
I am not like to die; and they who wait
Wax weary for my seat. I do not dote,
My lord Erizzo; Yet---
Foscari! Foscari!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: What mean those shouts?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Francesco Foscari!
There lives no other, whom a grateful people
Would greet as with one heart.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: My Lord Francesco!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: My son, my very son! Now I am young
And great and happy! Now I reign again,
My noblest son!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Father! Why this is joy
Deeper than victory! Dost feel my heart?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Art thou unhurt?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Untouched. I almost shame
To want one glorious scar. How well he is!
What fire is in his eyes! Cosmo, thou too!---
But I have tidings that the Doge must hear
Upon his throne. High tidings, gracious lords!
My father,---take thy state.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Lost! lost! All lost!
Another hour and that most hated boy
Had been most welcome!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Still as lovely, Cosmo?
And still as true?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Yes! Yes!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Will not the Doge
Assume the accustomed seat?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: My son, these lords,
These Senators, these mighty ones of Venice
Have found thy father old. Hadst thou returned
Some half hour later, thou hadst seen the throne
Filled by Donato, or his cousin Count.
Which hath thy voice, Francesco?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Thou not Doge!
Erizzo climb into thy honoured seat,
Honoured by thee! Or thou, Donato, thou
Join with this false, ungrateful, heartless senate,
This shadow and this mockery of wisdom,
To cast aside the best and truest heart
That ever made our Venice rich and proud
And great and happy, to throw off thy Prince
Like an old garment! Shame! Thou that didst call
Thyself his friend! Shame! shame! My dearest Cosmo,
This was a grief to thee. Oh shame! shame! shame!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Rated again, and by a boy! I tell thee
I would not be the Doge.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: My Lord Francesco,
Thy tidings.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Take thy state, Doge Foscari.
From thee did I receive my maiden sword,
From thee my high commission; to none other
Will I resign them. Senators of Venice!
Ingrates! I bring ye victory and peace.
Victorious peace! Brescia is free, and Milan
Sues at your feet for peace. Her haughty Duke
Is Sforza's prisoner,---my prisoner, Doge,
And Sforza weds his heir.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Eight days hence
He will be here. See what he writes, my lord.
The Senate is amazed; yet from the field
We sent ye somewhat of this glorious tale.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Those letters reached not Venice.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Count Erizzo,
I met the messenger, and staid my horse
To ask him of my father. He had stopt
Short of the palace, but had safely given
The packet to a Senator. Erizzo,
Thou wast the man. Look at him, ye that ever
Saw guilt ooze out in shame! Nay, tremble not;
I pardon thee. There is no other vengeance
For low dishonour. It would stain my sword
To dip it in thy blood.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: My Lord Francesco,
I yet may find a time---

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: I pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Sforza says here, this Brescian victory
Was gained by thee. Zeno, read there---just there.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Here is the treaty, Doge; already signed
By Milan, Sforza, and myself: add thou
Thy venerable name, Doge Foscari.
So---having crowned a long and glorious reign
With glorious peace, let me, thy son, pluck off
This envied bonnet from thy honoured head.
Wear it the worthiest! Never will it clip
Within its golden circlet such high thoughts,
Such a brave love of freedom, such a warm
And generous faith in man. Proud lords of Venice,
Ye ne'er deserved him. My good sword, lie there!
I am no more your general. Pass we forth
Together, my dear Father, private men---
Rich in the only wealth the world can give,
A spotless name.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Richest in thee. Nay, Zeno!

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Ye must not leave us, lords. Doge, if again
We had to chuse, our choice again would fall
On Foscari. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Sail with the stream---
Foscari!---I'll find a time---

sp.speaker: Senators.
sp.l: Foscari! Foscari!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: One still is silent.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Now, my Father, now!
For thy fame's sake.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: On Foscari.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Thanks! thanks!
Now dare I look upon that reverend face,
And grasp this hand again.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Did we not know thee!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Senators, countrymen, at your behest
I wear once more the crown.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Oh, no! no! no!
Bear not again that burthen.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: My Francesco,
Take up thy sword again, thy knightly sword---
I am too proud of thee!---thy stainless sword!
Now, good my lords, our fellow-citizens
Must be made happy in this glorious tale.
First to proclaim the peace; then, with meek hearts,
Lowlily, with a steadfast thankfulness
Pour out our homage to the Lord of Peace
In his own temple. This high duty o'er,
I bid ye to the palace; we must grace
Our soldier with some revelry. Donato,
Thou wilt be there, and Cosmo---will ye not?
And our Camilla, lady of the feast,
And of the heart. Come to us, dear Donato.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Are all his taunts forgotten?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: No! I cannot.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Think better of it, Zeno!---Follow soon,
Francesco!---Zeno, is this storm the end
Of our dark prophecy?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Signor Donato,
I have a feeling here of deep old love
That tells me I have wronged-thee. If I have,
Forgive me!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Father, canst thou turn away
When Foscari speaks those words which mortal ear
Ne'er heard him utter?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: If I did mistake,
'Twas in my Father's cause; 'twas such a wrong
As Cosmo would have done for thee. Forgive me,
For her dear sake.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Remember, "Shame!"

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Erizzo,
Think'st thou I can forget! Not even for her.
Stay me not, Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Go, for I can trust
Thy kind heart, Father! Love, who is so strong
In gentleness. Love and his bondman Time
Will conquer anger. We must now submit.
To-morrow---

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Oh! what a long life of love
Must I give up! To-morrow! I am here,
Here in this happy Venice, which she makes
The palace of her beauty, where the air
Is sweetened by her breath, and her young voice
Floats on the breeze like music. I am here---
Divided from her but by envious walls,
Clouds that conceal my sun. Had'st thou but seen
How I urged on my mettled courser's speed,
My matchless Barbary horse, till his pure jet
Was pounced with snowy flakes; or how I strove
To graft my hot impatience on the dull
And sluggish boatmen: or with what a stroke
I cleft the water; or how leapt ashore---

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: I can believe 't---

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: That I might sooner gain
By one half hour her presence! And to bear
This longing till to-morrow! Thou must say
All this and more, much more, of love and hope
And fond impatience. Tell her---

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Thou thyself
Shalt tell her these sweet things, mixed with a world
Of lovers' eloquence, of looks and sighs,
And broken words. Aye, Foscari, thou thyself!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: But how? Where? When?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: To night. For one short hour
Steal from the feast its hero. My good father,
Who, like a bird, fore-runs the summer sun,
Seeks his nest early. Thou mayst ask for me
And find Camilla.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Blessings on thee, friend!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: To night!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: We have a hearer.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: He is gone.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Beware that smooth Erizzo, dearest Cosmo,
Beware!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Nay, Foscari, let me caution thee
Beware suspicion! Think him innocent
Till thou hast proved him guilty. Blackening doubt
Beseems not thy clear breast. Sweep it away.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Oh, how I love the beautiful mistakes
Of thy unbounded charity! That man---
Didst thou not see him whispering Donato?
We will not think of him. Doth my Camilla
Talk of me often?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Oh, I was sure!
But it is such a joy to hear that yes!
Doth she---

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Hark! thou art called. The citizens
Demand their General. Go!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: I'd rather face
An enemy in battle.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Thou wast wont
To love the people, Foscari.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: I would drain
The last drop in my veins for them and freedom;
But these loud shouts, this popular acclaim,
This withering, perishing blast of vulgar praise,
Whose noisy echoes do shake off the flush
Of Fame's young blossoms---Oh, I hate them all!
True honour should be silent, spotless, bright,
Enduring; trembling even at the breath
That wooes her beauty.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Come.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: A Room in the Erizzo Palace.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Seek Signor Celso.---Baffled, spurned, contemned,
Pardoned---the insolent! But he shall feel---
All lost! For old Donato, shallow fool,
Hath in his anger a relenting spirit
And will yield easy way at the first tear
The fair Camilla sheds---the very first!
She hath but to cry Father, and to hang
About his neck and his light wrath will melt
Like snowflakes in that rain. How the dull Senate
Cowered at the haughty soldier's feet! Even I---
Thinks he I too can pardon! He shall find
My hate immortal. Nothing stands between
Me and the crown but Foscari. To-night---
This Celso, as I have good cause to know,
Can wield a dagger well---to-night he goes
To meet his lady love---to-night---alone---
I can detain young Cosmo.
Celso, friend,
Thou comest at a wish. Where hast thou been?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Where I am stunned with shouts of Foscari,
And dazzled with the glare of tinselled gauds
Hung out to honour him. The palaces
Are clothed with tissues, velvets, cloths of gold
And richer tapestry. The canals all strewed
With floating flowers, through which dark gondolas
Dart as through some bright garden. All is lost,
And I must leave dear Venice. Count, farewell!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Why must thou go?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Ask my hard creditors.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Celso, I have a thousand ducats here
For him that rids me of a clinging plague.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: A thousand ducats!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Hast thou still thy dagger?
In, and I'll tell thee more. This very night!

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: An Apartment in the Donato Palace.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Camilla, why so drooping?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: This hath been
A long and weary day; there is a heat,
A gloom, a heavy closeness. See, this rose
Is withering too, that was so fresh and fair---
The white musk-rose---that which he used to love.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: It was no day for Venice. 'Twould have been
A calm sweet stillness in our country home,
Bowered amid green leaves and growing flowers,
With fragrant airs about us, and soft light,
And rustling birds.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: The sky portends a storm.
To bed, Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Father! dearest father,
Have I displeased thee?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: No! To bed! To bed!
Laura, good night.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He used to call me child,
His dearest child; and when I grasped his hand
Would hold me from him with a long fond gaze,
And stroke my hair and kiss my brow, and bid
Heaven bless his sweet Camilla! And to night
Nought but to bed! to bed!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Believe it, Cousin,
A thing of accident.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And Cosmo comes not;
He sends not to me---he that never broke
His plighted word before! And Laura! Laura!
Foscari is in Venice, is returned
Triumphant, and he comes not, sends not, Laura!
And when I ask of him my father frowns
Sternly on his poor child.

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: My pretty-one,
I could not go to rest, till I had said
Heaven bless thee!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My dear father!

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: What is this?
A tear?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Oh! gratitude and love and joy
Are in that tear, dear father!---and one doubt---
One fear---

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Sweetest, good night!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Foscari, father?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: To bed my own Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not a word.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Something works in him deeply.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yet how kind,
How exquisitely fond! Cosmo must know,
And, Laura, Cosmo never flies from thee,
And thou may'st ask---

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: I will, I will, sweet Coz!
Look, dearest, at the glancing gondolas
Shooting along, each with its little light,
Like stars upon the water. Whither go they?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: To the proud Ducal Palace, where they hold
High feasting in his honour. There the dance,
And the quaint masque, and music's softer strains
Minister to his praises.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: And the ear
That would drink in so eagerly that sweet praise,
The heart that would leap up at every sound
Rejoicing, the glad eyes---Would thou wert there!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ah! would I were, since Foscari is there;
That is enough for me! Where'er he is,
In tent or battle-field---Hark! what is that?
That music? Oh 'tis he! 'tis Foscari!
Dost thou not know the strain, the wandering strain,
Trembling and floating like a spirit's song,
With many a---Hark again!---'Tis he! 'tis he!
That air belongs to him even as a name
It thrills my very heart. Am I not pale?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: No; the bright blood floats trembling in thy cheek,
Most like that wandering music.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: There is pain
In this excess of joy.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: He comes.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Camilla!
Sweetest Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Thou art come at last
Francesco!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: My Camilla---Come at last!
Why this is chiding! Can'st thou chide, Camilla?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Aye, or she were no woman.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Lady Laura!
Forgive me that I saw you not. Camilla,
Chide on---nay thou art smiling---Come begin!
I'd rather hear thy chidings than the praise
Of all the world beside. Let me but hear
Thy voice, whate'er thou speakest.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Dear Francesco,
Thou hast been long away.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Oh very long!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And where?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Away from thee. That is enough;
Where thou art not I keep no count of place
Nor time, nor speech, nor act.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yet tell me where.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Where I have dreamt of courts and camps and fields
Of glorious battle. A long weary dream
To him, who loves to bask him in thy smiles,
And live upon thy words.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yet hast thou lost
Ten weary hours to-day.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Why this, indeed,
Is chiding, my Camilla. I have been
At the Palace, at the Senate hall, at Church,
Have undergone a grand procession, love,
And a long dreary feast.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: And is that all?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: And is not that enough? Would'st thou crowd in
More tediousness? Oh thou unmerciful!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: But why not first---sure he is thinner, Laura,
Thinner and paler?

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Nay, he is the same.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Why not first come to me?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Perhaps I love
To visit my heart's treasure by that light
When misers seek their buried hoards; to steal
Upon the loved one, like a mermaid's song,
Unseen and floating between sea and sky;
To creep upon her in love's loveliest hour,
Not in her daylight beauty with the glare
Of the bright sun around her, but thus pure
And white and delicate, under the cool moon
Or lamp of alabaster. Thus I love
To think of thee, Camilla; thus with flowers
About thee and fresh air, and such a light,
And such a stillness; thus I dream of thee,
Sleeping or waking.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Dost thou dream of me?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Do I! without that lovely mockery,
That sweet unreal joy, how could I live
When we are parted? Do I dream of thee!
Dearest, what ails thee? Thou art not to night
As thou art wont, thine eyes avoid my gaze,
Thy white hand trembles and turns cold in mine.
What ails thee, dearest? Hast thou heard---What fear
Disturbs thee thus, Camilla?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I will tell thee.
Cosmo is absent; my dear father grieved;
There is high feasting in thy princely home
And I not there; and thou not here till now,
At midnight, when my father sleeps, and Cosmo
Is still away. Are ye all friends? Say Foscari
The very truth.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Well! Thou shalt hear the truth.
Cheer thee! 'Tis nought to weep for. At the Senate
There were to-day some hasty words.---Erizzo,
Thy subtle kinsman, he was most to blame---
I was too hot, too rash; but I implored
Donato's pardon, and am half forgiven;
Though yielding to the crafty Count, he shunned
To sup with us to-night.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ah! I had feared---

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: There is no cause for fear. This sudden storm
Is but a July shower that sweeps away
The o'erblown roses. Cosmo is our friend,
Our truest warmest friend; and well thou know'st
Thy father's kindly heart; he loves thee so;
Aye, and he loves me too; and he shall love me
Better than ever.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: He shall love! Lord Foscari
Thou'rt a true soldier. Wilt thou conquer love?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Surely.

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: And how?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: By love, and gratitude,
And deep respect, and true observance, Laura.
Shake not thy head, Camilla. He shall love me.
What is he not thy father! Smile on me.
Think'st thou that if I feared to lose thee I
Should be thus tranquil?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: No. But at my heart
There is a heavy sense of coming pain,
A deep and sad foreboding.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Thou hast been
Vexed to-day, sweetest, and thy weary thoughts
Tinge the bright future with the gloomy past.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Well, be it so. And yet I would to heaven
That this one night were over!---Where is Laura?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: She glided off, with a kind parting smile,
And a quick sparkle in her eye, that said
Ye will not miss me!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Aye, her merry glance;
But we do miss her. 'Twas a saucy thought,
My pretty gentle Laura!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: She is grown.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yes, tall and beautiful and rarely good.
Oh 'tis the kindest heart! We think she'll make---
What is that noise?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Nothing. A distant door.
What startles thee, Camilla?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My own heart.
Hark how it beats, painfully, fearfully!
Hush! hush! Again that noise!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: 'Tis thunder, love,
And that hath stirred thy spirits. Cheer thee, dearest;
A soldier's wife should be as brave as steel.
What did'st thou say of Laura?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: She will make
A sweet wife for our Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: And doth he
Love the young beauty?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He hath scarce forgot
To treat her as a child, the dearest child,
The loveliest and the gentlest,---but a child.
Francesco, thou must praise her---Ha! again!
That is no thunder-clap. My father's door!---
Oh go! go! go!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: My dear Camilla, no!
Thou can'st not fear me, I will be as calm,
As humble---

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Go! go! go! I die with fear;---
He is so rash, so sudden;---He will kill thee!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Here! Under his own roof! In thy dear sight!
Thy own dear father!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He will part us, Foscari!
Go!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Well, I go. But my Camilla---

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Go!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Dearest, farewell!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Not that way!---That! there! there!
Leap from the window in the corridor,
From the low balcony!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Farewell!

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I'm glad
That he is gone. Fear hath so mastered me
I stumble on the level floor. Thank heaven
They are both safe, my dearest Foscari,
My dearest father! There's no danger now;
And yet the night grows wilder. What a flash!
And I have sent him forth into the storm,
I, that so love him! I have sent him forth
Into this awful storm! Protect him, Heaven!
I thought I heard the window---Can those steps
Be his?

sp.speaker: Don.
sp.l: Help! help! base traitor! Foscari!
Murder!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Undo the door---I cannot---
Undo the door! My father!

sp.speaker: Laura.
sp.l: Who hath done
This horrible deed?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My father! muder! murder!

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: An illuminated Hall in the Ducal Palace.
Doge, Count Zeno, Ladies and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Now for some stirring air to wake the spirits
Of mirth and motion. Sweet ones, to the dance!
Where is this Foscari? Gentles, in my youth
He had been held a recreant that forsook
The revel, and the light of ladies' eyes,
And play of twinkling feet. Degenerate boy!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Degenerate days! Ah! we could tell such tales
Of the deep merriment, the gorgeous banquet,
The high festivity of our old time!
Thou may'st smile, Zeno, but his Highness knows
Bright mirth is on the wane. Our puny sons
Shew but faint flashes of their father's fire.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Believe him not, fair maids! 'Tis but the vaunt
Of vaunting age. Believe him not. Why, Moro,
Thy father in those mirthful days hath said
The same to thee, and his to him; yet still
'Tis merry Venice. Forty years to come
We, too, may boast us of our jovial prime,
Nor yet the world grow sadder. Fear it not.
His Highness will not join thee, Signor Moro;
He is too youthful-hearted.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: What a bribe
Is that to aid thy cause! But Moro's right;
We were fine gallants. Niece, I prythee see
That all are welcomed. Where's thy sister Melfi?

sp.speaker: 2nd Gent.
sp.l: Not yet returned from Rome.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I would have had
All the fair stars of Venice here to night
Shining in one bright galaxy.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: We miss
Signor Donato's daughter.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Aye, indeed,
My pretty sweet Camilla!---Fair Olivia,
Let Trevisano lead thee to the dance.
Were I one ten years younger, trust me, Sir,
I'd not resign this hand. Now a light measure.
Is't not a peerless nymph? The youngest Grace
Leading her linked sisters through the maze
Of blossom'd myrtles upon Ida's side,
Is not so light of foot. Rest thee, dear maid.
What is that? Thunder?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Yes; a fearful storm.
It rages awfully. Hark! there again!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Well; we must keep such coil of merriment
As shall outroar the rattling storm.
Ah, truant!
How wilt thou make thy peace?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: I read no war
In these fair looks.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Peace is more perilous.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Aye, truly, Zeno.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Whither hast thou been?
Watching her lattice but to catch a glimpse
Of the swift slender shadow that glides past
So gracefully, clouding the soft dim light?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Pooh! Pooh!

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: And with a true devotion bent
Uncovered at her shrine? Why thou art wet!
This is some new device of gallantry,
Some trick of Milan courtship.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Tush, man, tush!
Ho! a brisk measure! Drown with merry notes
Count Zeno's merry riddles! Wilt thou dance
With me, dear lady? Do not say me No!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Oh, no!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Why that should mean Oh yes!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Good niece,
Will not the Lady Claudia join the dance?
Seek her. I'm young and light enough to night
To mingle there myself. What ails the music?
Quicker! Why break they off? Dear Zeno ask.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Murdered! Impossible! I only left---
I am myself---It cannot be. Play on!
On with the dance!

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Here is a man hath seen him,
One who still shakes with fear.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Bring him to me!
Where is he? Where?

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Zeno, what is this tale?

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: A tale of horror!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Justice, Doge of Venice!
A Senator lies reeking in his blood,
Murdered in his own palace. Justice, Doge!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: What Senator?

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Canst thou ask that? Donato.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Donato murdered! the beloved Donato!
The second name of Venice! Mine old friend!
Lords, to the council. This is not a tale
For woman's gentleness. Good night to all.
Would he had ta'en my hand!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: He is not dead---
It must be false, it shall be!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: What dost thou
Doubt of Donato's death? Thou?

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Hearken, Doge!
His voice hath mockery in it, sharp and loud
As the clear ring of metals: he speaks not
As we, who heard the tale, in broken words
And breathless; his teeth chatter not; his lips
Are firm; there is no trembling in his limbs,
No glare in his keen eyes. None but a fiend,
Fresh from the reek of murder, could so master
The human sympathy, the fellowship
Of Nature and of kind.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Yet wherefore---

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Justice!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Beloved friend!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Off! Off! I come for justice,
For equal justice!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Thou shalt have it.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Doge!
For equal justice!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Was he not my friend?
Am I not thine?

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Aye---so the murderer said!---
Friend! the word chokes me.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Grief hath turned his brain.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Thou shalt have justice.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: 'Tis no midnight thief,
No hired assassin, no poor petty villain;---
This is a fall, as of the morning star,
A death such as the first great slayer saw
When Abel lay at his feet,---but I'll have justice!
There be hearts here will crack, old valiant hearts
When they shall hear this tale,---but I'll have justice!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Go some one call the guard.
Name the assassin.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Have I not! Whither doth he fly!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Camilla!
My poor Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Thine! And the earth hears him
And opens not her womb! The heavens hear
And launch no thunderbolts! This work is mine.
Hold firm my heart.---Cousin! Erizzo!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Seize
Francesco Foscari. Nay stand not thus
Gazing on one another. Seize him. Doge,
He is the murderer.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Away with thee,
Traitor and slanderer! He is my son---
Stir not a man of ye!---My son, the idol
Of city and of camp. His life hath been
One blaze of honour. Come to my old arms,---
Speak not a word---thy name is pledge enough
My son!

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Ye know your duty. Seize him, soldiers.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Approach me at your peril. Know you not
This very morning how yon serpent lay
Under my heel unbruised, a thing of scorn?
Look not upon us, lords, with doubting eyes,
Ye dare not doubt me---even to deny
Is in some sort a stain!---My shield is bright.
Ye force me to these vaunts! I could not think
A crime.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Bear hence the murderer.
Palsies wither
The cowardly arm and plotting brain that feared
To strike him dead at once!
Seize him, I say,

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Now he that dares!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Francesco Foscari,
I do arrest thee for this murder.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Thou!
Come forth into the light! Off with those plumes!
Look at me! Is this Cosmo? Hath some fiend
Put on that shape? Speak to me!

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Murderer!

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: To-day he called me brother!---Deal with me
Even as ye will.

sp.speaker: Eriz.
sp.l: Look to him, soldiers, well,
That he escape not.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Sir, the Foscari
Know not what that word means. I wait your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cos.
sp.l: Doge! Doth he hear me? Once I could have wept
For such a grief, for him; now I am steeled
By merciless misery, made pitiless
By one that hath no pity. Look! he stands
With such a calm of virtue on his brow,
As if he would outface the all-seeing God
With that proud seeming. Foscari, the dead
Shall cry aloud in heaven, and I on earth,
Till vengeance overtake thee. Doge of Venice,
I call on thee for justice on thy son.

sp.speaker: Fos.
sp.l: Father!---Oh, start not!---I am innocent.
Hear that, and breathe again. Sir, I commit
My life, my honour, the unsullied name
Of my great ancestors, of him the greatest
My living father---even his name I trust
To my just cause, and the just laws of Venice.
I am your prisoner.
sp.stage: Exeunt Foscari, guarded, Erizzo and Cosmo.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Doge!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Those lights! Those lights!
They pierce my eye-balls, dart into my brain!
If there be any pity left i' the world
Make me a darkness and a silence, Zeno,
That I may pray.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Lead to his chamber, Sirs.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Is all prepared for trial?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: All. The Doge
Approaches.

sp.speaker: Senator.
sp.l: Will the Doge preside?

sp.speaker: 2nd Senator.
sp.l: He comes.
How different from his step of yesterday!
How hurried, yet how slow!

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Let me assist
Your Highness.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: His robes encumber him;
Support them.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Why will you torment me, Sir,
With this officious care? These flowers are naught.
Go bring me pungent herbs, hyssop and rue
And rosemary; odours that keep in sense---
I have forgot my handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Take this.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I am an old man newly stung with grief---
Thou hast forgiven me, Zeno? Are ye ready?
Where is the accuser?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: May it please your Highness
Call forth the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Oh not thou good Doge;
Spare those white hairs!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Dare not to pity me!
Sir, those white hairs are lichens on a rock.
I tell ye, Sirs, since yesternight my blood
Is dried up in my veins, my heart is turned
To stone; but I am Doge of Venice still
And know my office. Fear me not, Francesco!
Francesco Foscari---Sir, is he there?
My eyes are old and dim.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: I am here Father!
Doge! I am here.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Francesco Foscari
Thou art arraigned for the foul midnight murder
Of the senator Donato. Art thou innocent?
Or guilty?

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Canst thou ask? The fresh-born babe
That knows not yet the guiltiness of thought,
Is not from such crime whiter.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Gracious heaven
I thank thee! Now the weight is off my soul.
I sinned in my black fear. Where's the accuser?
Let him stand forth. Cosmo---Signor Donato,
Speak.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Look with how calm and proud a mien
The murderer stands, whilst the poor son conceals
His face against the wall.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Speak, pr'y thee, speak.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Alas! alas! I cannot. We were friends
Even from earliest childhood. I loved him---
Oh how I loved him! Aye and he loved me,
With a protecting love, the firmest love;
For stronger, bolder, hardier, he to me
Was as an elder brother. And his home
Was mine, and mine was his---Oh he has sate
A hundred times on that dear father's knee,
His little head nestling against that breast,
Where now---Oh Foscari, hadst thou slain me
My last word had been pardon! But my father,
And with a stedfast and unaltering cheek
To listen---

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Cosmo! I am innocent.
Yet, Heaven knows, I grieve---

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Camilla's father---
Poor, poor Camilla!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Ah thou hast it now!
'Tis a fair woman's soft and liquid name
That stings thy soul! Good, good.---Ho! Officer!
sp.stage: Apart to an Officer, giving him a paper.
sp.l: Deliver that and bring the witness hither,
Look thou take no excuse.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Signor Donato,
I pray you check these pardonable tears.
Were this a place for passion, what's thy grief
Measured with mine? The death of all thy name
To this suspense, this agony, this shame,
That eats away the soul? What is thy grief---
Master thyself, I say. Francesco Foscari
Stands there to answer to thy charge of murder.
Produce thy proofs.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Bring in the corse. My Lord
And ye, the equal judges, spare the son
This miserable duty. I can tell,
For I by chance was there, this tale of blood
And mystery. The late unhappy feud
Is known to all. Returning from St. Mark's
With my young kinsman in his Gondola---
For I had missed of mine---we landed close
To the Donato Palace, as the bell
Was tolling midnight. 'Twas an awful storm;
But by the flashing lightning we saw one
Leap from the balcony---a Cavalier
Splendid in dress and air. The lightning glared
Full on his face and habit, unconcealed
By hat or cloak, and instantly we knew
Francesco Foscari.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Art sure of that?

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Oh sure! Too sure!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: He passed so close Count Zeno,
That my cloak brushed his vest; but sprang aside,
As he had met an adder, and leaped down
Into a waiting Gondola. I called,
But Foscari answered not; and Cosmo spake,
Betwixt a sigh and smile, of fair Camilla,
Of their long loves, and of the morning's ire,
And how he hoped this dark and sudden cloud
Would speedily pass away. Even as he spake,
Whilst loitering on the steps, we heard a shriek
Within the house, so piercing, so prolonged,
So born of bitter anguish---to this hour
That shriek is ringing in mine ears! And when,
With trembling hearts and failing limbs, we scaled
The stairs, we saw Donato bathed in blood,
And poor Camilla lying on his breast,
Her arms strained round his neck, as if she tried
To keep in his dear life.
The bloody witness
Of this foul deed is here.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Poor good old man!
This is a grievous sight.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Oh! Would to Heaven
That I so lay, and so---I pray thee, on.
Where are thy proofs?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: They shall come soon enough.
Donato, rouse thee! Look upon those wounds!
Think on the honoured dead!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: I dare not think,
For thought is frenzy. Lords! The Count Erizzo
Hath told ye how we found the corse. This sword,
The well-known sword of Foscari, was plunged
Deep in his gory breast; beside him lay
This hat and cloak, the splendid soldier's garb
Of Foscari; no man had approached the house
Save only Foscari; and his last word,
Mingled with cries of murder and of help,
Was "Foscari." Is that sword thine? Disown it,
And, against oath and proof and circumstance.
Thy word---thy naked word---Disown that sword,
And give me back the blessed faith that trusts
In man my fellow! Look upon it well.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: 'Tis mine.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: He's guilty. 'Twas the last faint hope
On this side Heaven.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Cosmo! It is not his---
He knows not what he says---Give me the sword.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: 'Tis mine; that which lay sheathed in victory
Before ye yesterday; that which I bore
Triumphing through the battle. What a blaze
Streamed from the sparkling steel---how bright, how pure,
How glorious, how like the light of Fame---
A wild and dazzling fire! Both, both are quenched.
The sword is mine; but of this foulest deed
I am as ignorant as the senseless blade.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Who heard Donato call on Foscari?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Doge, thou hast asked for proofs, for witnesses;
I have one here. Officer, hast thou brought
The lady?

sp.speaker: Officer.
sp.l: She attends.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Go lead her in.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: What lady? Sure thou canst not mean---

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: She walks as in a heavy dream; her senses
Are stupified by sorrow. Count Erizzo,
Why dids't thou send for her? Why bring her here?
Had we not breaking hearts enow before
Without poor, poor Camilla?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: She alone
Heard his last dying words. Lady Camilla!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: She neither sees nor hears; she is herself
A moving corse.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Camilla! Speak to her.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Sister! Heaven shield her senses! She is deaf
Even to my voice. Dear sister!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Lead her towards
The body. So! she sees it.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Father! Father!
Have I found thee dear father? Let me sit
Here at thy feet, and lean my aching head
Against thy knee---Oh how it throbs!---and bury
My face within thy cloak. What ails me, Father,
That my heart flutters so? Feel here---He's cold!
He's dead! He's dead!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Camilla!

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Who art thou?
Where am I? Wherefore have ye dragged me forth
Into the glare of day---Oh cruel! cruel!---
Amongst strange men? Where am I? Foscari! Now
I have a comforter. Have they not told thee
That I am fatherless? Dost weep for me?
For me?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Leave him; he is a murderer.
Thy father's murderer!

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Who dared say that?
Francesco, speak to me!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Pollute her not!
Touch not her garments! Fly his very sight---
He slew thy Father.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Ha! Again! Again!
Cosmo, this man is false. Is he not Cosmo?
Is he not all one falsehood? Answer me.
I will kneel to thee, Cosmo, for a word,
A sign. Press but my hand. He lets it fall!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Sister---I cannot tell her.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Thou thyself
Art witness to his crime.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: I never knew
Aught of him but his virtues.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Noble lady,
Thou art before the assembled power of Venice,
Before thy father's corse, before high Heaven---
Answer me truly, lady---Didst thou hear
Thy murdered father call on Foscari?

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Ah!---He is innocent.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Didst thou not hear
Foscari's name mixed with his dying shriek?

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: He's innocent! Oh I would stake my life
On Foscari's innocence.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Beloved child:

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Ah! Art thou there? Release him; Set him free!
Thou art the Doge, the mighty Doge of Venice,
Thou hast the power to free him.---Save him now
From my hard kinsman! Save him! I remember,
When I was but a little child, I craved
The grace of a poor galley slave, and thou
Didst pardon him and set him free as air;---
Wilt thou not save thy son, and such a son,
Who is as clear of this foul sin as thou?
Cosmo, kneel with me!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: I have knelt for justice;
And now again---

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: For mercy! mercy!

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Answer!
Demand her answer, Doge. She is a witness,
Command her by thy power; thou art the Judge.

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: I am, I am. Ye should have Dukes of stone,
But this is flesh. Camilla, I am not
A King, who wears fair mercy on the cross
Of his bright diadem; I have no power
Save as the whetted axe to strike and slay,
A will-less instrument of the iron law
Of Venice. Daughter---Thou that should'st have been
My daughter, we are martyrs at the stake,
And must endure. Shall we not copy him,
Who stands there, with so brave a constancy,
Patient, unfaltering? Let us chuse the right,
And leave the event to Heaven. Speak, my dear child.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Heaven guide me then! Lords, I am here an orphan,
The orphan of one day.---But yesternight---
Oh! did ye ever see a father die?

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Calm thee my sister.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: And ye drag me hither---
Ye call me to bear witness---me, a woman;
A wretched helpless woman!---Against him,
Whom---ye are merciless---ye have no touch
Of pity or of manhood! Do your worst;
I will not answer ye.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Oh woman's love,
Pure nurse of kind and charitable thoughts,
Wiser than wisdom, instinct of the soul,
How do I bless thee holiest love! Camilla,
My brave and true Camilla, thou hast dropt
Balm in the festering wound. Yet answer them.
I cannot fear the truth. Ask her once more.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Were not the last words that Donato spake
Foscari and murder?

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Take her away;
She hath confessed enough.

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: Oh no! no! no!
Foscari is guiltless! Hear me!---He is guiltless!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Canst thou prove that? Thy sweet face always brought
A comfort. Prove but that.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: All curses on
The coward Celso! He'll escape me yet.
The facts? The proofs? The witnesses?

sp.speaker: Camilla.
sp.l: His life;
My heart, my bursting heart. If I had seen
With these poor eyes that horror---had seen him
Stabbing---Oh, thoughts like these may make me mad,
But all the powers of earth and hell can never
Shake my true faith! Foscari! I will share
Thy fate, will die with thee, will be thy bride
Even in that fatal hour, and pass away
With thee to Heaven---So! so!

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: She sinks; she sinks;
Her strength is over-wrought. Oh die not yet
Till I may die with thee! Awake, revive,
My plighted love! The bridal hour will soon
Unite us my Camilla. Help! she faints.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Fold her not thus within thy arms! Resign her!

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: To thee! While still this arm hath marrow in it!
To thee! Cosmo---thou---thou---Be tender of her,
Be very tender---'tis a broken flower---
And pardon her her love. Take her. The pain
Of death is over now. Proceed, my lords.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: Let me support her, Cosmo. Thou dost stagger
Under her slender form.

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: He spake to me,
He gazed on me---I felt the long sad look
Dwell on my face---he, at whose crime my soul
Shudders, he spake---and I---men would have thought
I was the guilty one! He bade me love
This dearest, wretchedest. Tell him---No! no!
Not even a last word.

div.stage: Exeunt Cosmo and Zeno, with Camilla.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: This hapless maid
Hath owned enough. Foscari, wilt thou confess
The murder?

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Confess;
Or we must force confession. To the rack!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Never whilst I have life! Am I not still
The Doge of Venice? Rather stretch these stiff
And withered limbs upon thy engines, Count!
Rather crack these old joints! I thought that I
Was steeled against all strokes---but this---

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: The rack!

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Bethink thee of the Roman fathers, Doge,
Of Brutus and of Manlius; thy son
Will not disgrace thee. Come, the rack, the rack!
I will front pain as a brave enemy,
And rush to the encounter. What is the sense
Of bodily agony to that which I
Endure even now? Disgrace, suspicion, scorn,
Hatred and haughty pity, and that last
Worst pang---her love, her misery. These are tortures!
Let me have something that a warrior's soul
May strive against and conquer. Come, the rack!

sp.speaker: Doge.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: I must not hear thee, Doge. The question!

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Stop, on your lives! Forbear this cruelty,
This cowardly cruelty! He will endure---
He will call up the courage of the field
And die before he groans. His eye surveys
That engine steadily, whose very sight
Makes my flesh creep. Remove it. Oh to see
That butchery---and the old man---the poor old man!
Remove it.

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: Well. Proceed we then to sentence.

sp.speaker: Zeno.
sp.l: First listen to the prisoner. Foscari! speak.

sp.speaker: Senator.
sp.l: Yes; let us hear his tale. Defend thyself.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: To ye who doubt! To ye who disbelieve!
Sir, there are spirits that can never stoop
To falsehood; not for wealth, or power, or fame,
Or life, or dearer love. Oh, were ye cast
In the old chivalrous mould, pure diamond souls
On which the dim polluting touch of doubt
Rests not a breathing time! Were ye built up
Of honour---But to ye---Why should I speak
When I have nothing but my knightly word
To prove me innocent?

sp.speaker: Erizzo.
sp.l: You are well paid
By this contempt, Count Zeno. Now to judgment.
sp.stage: The Doge, Zeno, Erizzo, and the Senators retire to the back of the stage, leaving Cosmo and Foscari in the front.

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: Father! He passes on and doth not speak;
He cannot; he has no words,---nothing but tears.
Oh, what must the grief be that forces tears
From his proud heart---his proud and bursting heart!
The flame of youth burnt in him yesterday
At fourscore years; to-day hath made him old.
What groan was that? What other wretch? Donato!
Cosmo! Wilt thou not answer?

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Oh that voice
Which was such perfect music,---which seemed made
For truth and thought, fit organ, how it jars
My very soul! What would'st thou?

sp.speaker: Foscari.
sp.l: I would thank thee
That thou hast spared one pang to a brave heart.
That rack---To have seen me stretched there, to direct
Each fresh progressive torture.---He had died
Before our eyes! I thank thee, sir. No more.
Unless a dying man, for I am sentenced---
Look how he sinks his head upon his clenched
And withered hands! I am condemned, and we
Shall meet no more. Thou wilt not join the headsman
To see the axe fall on my neck, nor follow
The shouting multitude who, yesterday,
Hail'd me a god, and, with like shouts, to-morrow
Will drag me to the block. We meet no more;
And as a dying man I fain would part
In charity. We were friends, Cosmo.---

sp.speaker: Cosmo.
sp.l: Friends!
I sinned in listening; but whilst he spake
A world of kindly thoughts, a gush of the deep
Old passionate love came o'er my heart---Forgive me
Oh blessed shade! Friends! Why thy crime were common
Wanting that damning dye---a simple murder!
What though of one kind, noble, generous,
Whose princely spirit scattered happiness
